• KEVIN K CHEN.
  • words on "stereotype threat"
  • september 13, 2014

    • There have been two broad event where I felt stereotype threat: In writing and in interviewing.

    Being Asian, reading and writing was never my friend growing up. From kindergarten throughout first grade, all I did was write one sentence stories and summaries of other books -- something akin to "I like Halloween." Throughout middle school, I wasn't even sure what I was writing half the time. Then, on the SATs, I had no clue where to start, even after I had finished all the prep classes.

    At every juncture, I went into writing with the fear that I wasn't going to do stellar anyway. So, I might as a well just try to get a 650 instead of a 700 on the SAT. I might as well just aim for a A- or B+, never the A.

    Likewise, as I've graduated from college and have interviewed at a plethora of jobs, I have noticed that I still undergo similar problems regarding being "Asian".

    In movies, you find that Asians aren't presented as the most articulate. Especially in the U.S., they struggle to deal with their emotions. As a result, the only time they muster their rhetoric skills together is in a moment of frustration or release.

    Suffice it to say, whenever I interviewed for internship positions early-on in my college career, I would struggle to even say, "Hi", and make small talk in any comfortable way. This made me question whether I should even pursue some of the careers that I think I would've enjoyed. Moreover, I questioned whether it was even worth developing interview skills for this and any business job.

    There are ways to overcome the stereotyping voice inside yourself. It's not immediate, but gradual. They're simple, but nonetheless mentally, emotionally, and physically painful -- there's nothing worse than failing over and over again for years.

    I think it all starts with a question of desire (I refrain to use passion b/c it's, so misconstrued). Whether it's an actual desire because you think, say, reading and writing are cool or just a desire to be better, that desire needs to be there. Desire has no boundaries.

    On the eve of my last SAT, I took some time to think "why" I was taking the test. I had no choice, sure, but humans have a natural gift for rationalizing what they do. In this case, I knew I wanted to be better. Just, generally better. And I could only really stretched myself by going to a great college. I had the grades -- so it was clear I was able to push past previous hurdles. What if I took this test without thinking about my limits? There's no reason why I couldn't score higher than 650.

    Likewise, in interviewing, I knew that I could converse with people until 3am at night. Why couldn't I take that same impassioned debater within and make a case for why I should be hired?

    It's easy to write about all these doubts and fears, each of which are a half decade to two decades old. It wasn't overnight, it took years. But, I eventually scored a perfect on the SAT Verbal. And, after talking to a colleague at an old firm, he mentioned that I was the only candidate that the interview panel unequivocally agreed on.

    Likewise, going into DBC, I suppose my biggest stereotypes I have about myself are the opposite now. I'm not "Asian" enough because I didn't studied something technical in college, I haven't studied math in half a decade. I'm not super-logical, I make leaps to judgment (probably because of my study as a historian).

    I realize that I will encounter pain in trying to stretch my brain. But, I am not too worried about being worried. Coding, as most areas of study, will come with time. So, when I encounter moments of stereotype threat. I will be clear to remind myself of all the hurdles I have overcome. Likewise, I'll be sure to remind others of their past abilities that continue to drive their success into the future.
